(1 comment)
Abandoned
It would be good to add a comment to Memory.MemoryECC that the interface is deprecated as well.
Updated.

I have trouble understanding how OS and BIOS/UEFI report UE/CE counts in a way that we'd want the BMC to model.  If the OS is reporting an error, it is pertaining to some piece of hardware such as Memory, right?  So wouldn't it be the responsibility of the BMC to take the memory errors reported by the OS and BIOS and combine them into a single reading?  Errors should be associated with a piece of hardware and not associated with the reporting entity.

As my opinion, beside the hardware, the OS and UEFI also have their CE/UE errors. Maybe we don't have inventory from them but they still can have the error and it would like to log in BMC to be monitor by admin.

What is an "OS CE error"?  This is why I'm questioning this.  I don't know what is is.  The OS could potentially detect CEs with all sorts of hardware.  The statistic should be associated with the hardware, otherwise it is useless.

The "CE OS error" can be the service is corrupted but can be recovered, or crash of process but it will be restarted after that.
The "UE OS error" can be "blue screen" error, OS crashed and have to restart OS. I think.
To me that feels like stretching the purpose of the interface. I'd prefer that it has a relatively strong definition around hardware data integrity problems and isn't used to address software bugs.
Updated commit message to remove "OS, BIOS/UEFI"
Does this match your name on the Ampere CCLA?  Please adjust your git-config if necessary.
Updated.
Commit is failing CI because you didn't run the script in `gen` to regenerate the meson for the new interface.
Updated.
I'd like to see more documentation about how this is intended to be used.  It isn't obvious from the current documentation and I could see this leading to different opinions / implementations.

This field is updated by phosphor-ecc.
That repo has one max_log.cfg file, when the number of CE/UE error more than that configuration value. The isLoggingLimitReached will be true. https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-ecc/tree/master.
I think it is reasonable to have this field. If there is no max error configuration we can use MAX size value (255).
We also need this field for backward compatible if we want to deprecated the memoryECC interface.

https://github.com/search?q=org%3Aopenbmc%20isLoggingLimitReached&type=code

Considering there are no real users of it, we can just deprecate the property and remove it from the new interface.  Just because someone dreamed something up once doesn't mean we have to support it forever.  It hasn't found utility in 4 years, so we can remove it.
Updated.
size
Updated.
size
Updated.
I don't understand the purpose of this.  Can't you tell it from the earlier properties?  Why duplicate the same information in a different property?

As my opinion, we don't need this property.
We can remove this field, I think.
Any comment Andrew?

But removing this field will require the changing in phosphor-ecc if we want that repo use this interface instead of MemoryECC.
If we remove the isLoggingLimitReached, then we don't have the state "Full log" in that case do we keep this field?
Done
Generally enums are capitalized.  "Ok".
Updated.
No ECC errors have occurred.
Updated.
Please spell out.
Updated.

Absolutely not.

Please add an association to an inventory item.

This was my suggestion. I figured it might help filter counters of interest before we go and resolve any associations. I'm not wedded to it though. Associations certainly would carry the at least the same information.
The problem is that people will perpetually want to add to it.  Everyone is going to have their custom accelerator card, etc.  Associations are the way to go.
Ack

I've revisited my thoughts on the name and figure "ErrorStatistic" should probably be plural (ErrorStatistics) as there are multiple counters:

```
yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Integrity/ErrorStatistics.interface.yaml
```
Updated.
Done

Is it worth being explicit about how the counts are maintained? Are we counting from when we last applied power to the system? Or since the system was manufactured? Over the last hour?

It's not clear as it stands.
I think the last power to the system. I think the administrator will much care about that value then the others.
Done
I think my preference is "Metrics.Integrity." on these.  There are other people working on other metrics and these seem like they belong in the same top-level directory.
Updated.
nit: CECount
Updated.
nit: UECount
Updated.
Please look at `requirements.md`.  These associations are not named in accordance with those.
Updated. Can you take a look.
I don't mind if you want to have a boolean like this one in your new interface, but I'd like a more succinct name.
I added CEExceed and UEExceed to identify the state which those error count over the limitation.
Done

A bit of a two-second thought, but wouldn't it be more informative to provide `CELimit` and `UELimit` members instead of `CEExceed` and `UEExceed`? This way whether or not we've breached the acceptable limit is just a comparison: `CECount > CELimit`.
Updated.

this describes a threshold and I'll suggest we seek patterns from those sensors.

however I'll also state that a practical threshold is likely events within a given time interval.   for example PCIe has a target bit error rate and larger memories expect a rate of correctable errors due to cosmic radiation upsetting a cell.

Could we implement that with `[CU]ETimeWindow` properties? If they're set to 0, then there's no time window defined and the `[CU]ELimit` is absolute, otherwise if `[CU]ETimeWindow > 0` then `[CU]ELimit` is the upper bound of errors inside `[CU]ETimeWindow`?
This seems reasonable.
Any comment @Patrick Williams?

Thu,
There is a generic way to handle the metrics using Value and Threshold interface. There is a PR in review for this https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/64914 and corresponding design document https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/docs/+/64917.

Can you please have a look at that.
Ack
